author: By Paul Krugman
title: Keep Your Eye on the Three F’s
description: The Fed, fiscal policy and food prices are putting the brakes on America’s boom.
content: High inflation in the United States basically reflects two forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: State attorneys general ask Snap and TikTok to give parents more control over apps.
description: Concerns that popular social media platforms can expose children to posts that are sexualized, hurt their body image or are violent have escalated in recent years.
content: A group of attorneys general on Tuesday asked Snap and TikTok to work more closely with parental control apps and to apply more scrutiny to inappropriate content on their platforms, the latest salvo in a growing fight over child protection between governments and social media companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Some Signs of Progress in Talks
description: Russia says it will scale back from Kyiv and Ukraine offers talks on Crimea.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Coronavirus deaths in the U.S. fall to their lowest point since the summer.
description: Fewer than 800 coronavirus deaths are being reported each day in the United States, the lowest daily average since before the Omicron variant took hold late last fall. The last time the rate was this low was in mid-August, according to a New York Times database.
content: Fewer than 800 coronavirus deaths are being reported each day in the United States, the lowest daily average since before the Omicron variant took hold late last fall. The last time the rate was this low was in mid-August, according to a New York Times database.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: A Vow to Ease Bombing Is Too Late for Many in Ukraine City Near Kyiv
description: Russia’s offer, if honored, will not help the thousands who have already fled Chernihiv.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Thousands of people have been fleeing the northern outskirts of the Ukrainian capital, Kyiv, escaping towns and villages under attack by Russian troops across the region. Many of them are from the city of Chernihiv, with bleak faces and crushing stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: What Would You Like to Ask Your 40-Year-Old Self?
description: What do you want to know about the future? Why?
content: If you could go decades ahead in time and ask your 40-year-old self some questions, what would you ask? Why? Be as specific as you can. What questions would you have about how your life turned out? About the lives of loved ones? About local, national and world events? Inventions? Arts and culture?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Gabby Sobelman
title: Palestinian Gunman Kills 5 in Israel’s Fifth Attack in Recent Days
description: The attack in a Tel Aviv suburb brought the number of people killed in the past two weeks to 11, making it one of the deadliest periods in Israel in several years.
content: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian gunman killed five people in an ultra-Orthodox city outside of Tel Aviv on Tuesday night, the latest in a surge of attacks in Israel this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Condé Nast workers form a companywide union.
description: The union will cover more than 500 employees from all of Condé Nast’s brands, except the four publications that have already unionized.
content: Hundreds of workers at the publishing giant Condé Nast, which owns titles like Vogue, Vanity Fair, Bon Appétit and GQ, announced on Tuesday that they had formed a companywide union. The Condé Nast Union is affiliated with the NewsGuild of New York, which also represents editorial employees at The New York Times as well as other publications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanna Scutts
title: Today We’d Call Her a Progressive Heroine. She’d Have Hated It.
description: In “Diamonds and Deadlines,” Betsy Prioleau tells the story of the extravagant, ruthless Gay Nineties media tycoon Miriam Leslie.
content: DIAMONDS AND DEADLINES
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra Newman
title: In a Climate Crisis, the Future Relies Alarmingly on Big Tech
description: With her novel “A House Between the Earth and the Moon,” Rebecca Scherm creates a world that embodies the anxiety and indignity of our times.
content: A HOUSE BETWEEN THE EARTH AND THE MOONBy Rebecca Scherm
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Sanctioned Oligarch’s Presence Adds Intrigue to Ukraine-Russia Talks
description: Roman Abramovich, sanctioned owner of the Chelsea Football Club, mysteriously showed up at the talks between Ukraine and Russia in Istanbul, and is said to be playing an unofficial role.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — When diplomats from Russia and Ukraine met for talks in the 19th-century Dolmabahce Palace in Istanbul on Tuesday, their host urged the antagonists to reach a cease-fire “to the benefit of everyone.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kerri Arsenault
title: From Family Trees to 23andMe, and Back Again
description: Maud Newton’s “Ancestor Trouble” is a sweeping genealogical investigation that becomes an investigation of genealogy itself.
content: ANCESTOR TROUBLEA Reckoning and a ReconciliationBy Maud Newton
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Oscars audience grew by 555,000 after Will Smith slapped Chris Rock.
description: But the largest audience of the night was tuned in earlier, during Troy Kotsur’s win for best supporting actor.
content: The Oscars audience swelled by more than half a million people on Sunday shortly after Will Smith slapped Chris Rock, capping the awards show with a late-night surge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Americans, especially Republicans, are getting more worried about inflation.
description: Recent poll data suggests that rising prices dominate Americans’ economic concerns, with inflation fears the highest since 1985.
content: Americans are more worried about inflation than at any point since 1985, and that concern is quickly escalating, according to a new poll, a potential problem for Democrats and the White House ahead of the midterm elections in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Liu and Paul Mozur
title: Shanghai’s Lockdown Tests Covid-Zero Policy, and People’s Limits
description: A staggered lockdown on China’s commercial capital of 26 million people has sent beleaguered residents scrambling and raised fears of broader damage to the economy.
content: Even before Shanghai imposed a lockdown to curb a rapidly spreading Covid outbreak, life for many in China’s wealthiest city had been upended by the virus — and the government’s response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Sheinbaum
title: No Wedding Photographer? No Problem.
description: Between vendor shortages, Covid restrictions and budget concerns, some couples are relying on phone cameras and instant photography to capture their big day.
content: When Leah Hartman, 32, and Titouan Chapouly, 30, were married on Oct. 29 at the city clerk’s office in Manhattan, their friend, Sydney Kipen, played the role of stylist, guest, witness … and wedding photographer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court, in Case on Veteran Hurt by Burn Pits, Debates War Powers
description: The justices seemed split on whether Congress can allow suits against states that discriminate against injured service members returning from conflicts.
content: WASHINGTON — A Supreme Court argument on Tuesday about an Army reservist injured by burn pits in Iraq turned into a seminar on the scope of Congress’s war powers, federalism, the Vietnam War and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: The War Is Reshaping How Europe Spends
description: Romania is buying iodide pills. Ireland enacted special incentives for its farmers to till essential crops. And military spending is rising across the continent.
content: Nicolae Ciuca spent a lifetime on the battlefield before being voted in as prime minister of Romania four months ago. Yet even he did not imagine the need to spend millions of dollars for emergency production of iodide pills to help block radiation poisoning in case of a nuclear blast, or to raise military spending by 25 percent in a single year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas and Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. to Change Postseason Overtime Rule After Bills’ Playoff Loss
description: Each team will now get at least one overtime possession in playoff games.
content: PALM BEACH, Fla. — The N.F.L.’s 32 clubs passed a rule change on Tuesday to ensure that both teams would possess the ball at least once in overtime of postseason games. The measure comes months after Kansas City won a divisional round playoff game against the Buffalo Bills, who were not given a chance to score in overtime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: Do Russian Oligarchs Have a Secret Weapon in London’s Libel Lawyers?
description: How a group of attorneys worked to keep negative stories about President Vladimir Putin’s allies out of the British media for decades.
content: LONDON — There were plenty of rave reviews for “Putin’s People,” a 2020 best seller about the Russian president’s inner circle, but a small group of spectacularly rich men hated the book and they didn’t hide their feelings. Over the course of a few weeks, all of them filed suit against the author, Catherine Belton, and her publisher, HarperCollins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Gunmen Attack Train Near Nigerian Capital, Killing Some Riders
description: The attackers used explosives to blow up the rail track before opening fire on the train in the latest in a series of train assaults.
content: ABUJA, Nigeria — Gunmen attacked a train near Nigeria’s capital on Monday night with explosives and gunfire, killing an unspecified number of the nearly 1,000 passengers on board, authorities and survivors told The Associated Press on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: Reports of sexual violence involving Russian soldiers are multiplying, Ukrainian officials say.
description: A Ukrainian woman’s account of being repeatedly raped was published in The Times of London, and a member of Ukraine’s Parliament said there were “many more” such assaults.
content: The crime first came to light last week, when Ukraine’s prosecutor general, Iryna Venediktova, said in a Facebook post that a Russian soldier had killed an unarmed civilian and then repeatedly raped his wife. Days later, the White House said it was concerned about emerging reports of sexual violence in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: The Best Room in Your Home? It Could Be the Laundry Room.
description: Don’t laugh: These days, a laundry room isn’t something to hide — it’s a place to show off. Here’s how to make yours shine.
content: Laundry rooms were once utilitarian spaces hidden away in basements or small, windowless rooms. But not anymore: Now they’re getting the full designer treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Gabler
title: How 2 Industries Stymied Justice for Young Lead Paint Victims
description: The U.S. insurance and real estate industries have waged a decades-long campaign to avoid liability in lead cases, helping to prolong an epidemic. The cost for millions of children has been incalculable.
content: When Selena Wiley signed the lease for an older rental home in South Bend, Ind., she asked the property manager about lead paint and was assured the house was safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Signs Bill to Make Lynching a Federal Crime
description: President Biden’s signature ended more than 100 years of failed efforts by the federal government to specifically outlaw lynching.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Tuesday signed a bill making lynching a federal crime, for the first time explicitly criminalizing an act that had come to symbolize the grim history of racism in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William McDonald
title: Joan Joyce, Dominant in Women’s Softball, Is Dead at 81
description: Her pitching feats — including striking out Ted Williams — were legend. And with her prowess extending to basketball, volleyball and golf, many saw all-around athletic greatness.
content: On a warm August night in 1961, Ted Williams, the “Splendid Splinter” who had finished his Hall of Fame baseball career the year before as the last hitter to bat .400 in a single season, strode to the plate before an overflow crowd at Municipal Stadium in Waterbury, Conn., to face a young softball pitching phenom by the name of Joan Joyce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: F.D.A. Allows Second Coronavirus Boosters for Everyone 50 and Older
description: People in the age group can get the additional shot at least four months after their first booster. Those 12 and older with certain immune deficiencies are also eligible.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators authorized second booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna coronavirus vaccines on Tuesday for everyone 50 and older, describing the move as an effort to bolster waning immunity against severe disease in case the virus sweeps the nation again in the coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Ackerberg
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Friendship, Betrayal and the Fight: “Suffs” Tells the Suffragist Tale in Song’
description: In this lesson, students will read about a new musical that explores women’s fight for the right to vote, listen to the songs and create a poster for their own possible theater production.
content: Featured Article: “Friendship, Betrayal and the Fight: ‘Suffs’ Tells the Suffragist Tale in Song”  by Jennifer Schuessler
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Christopher Alexander, Architect Who Humanized Urban Design, Dies at 85
description: A fierce anti-modernist, he championed vernacular structures, becoming a counterculture hero to many, from New Urbanists to software designers to Prince Charles.
content: Christopher Alexander, the Viennese-born professor, architect and theorist who believed that ordinary people, not just trained architects, should have a hand in designing their houses, neighborhoods and cities, and proposed a method for doing so in writing that could be poetically erudite, frustratingly abstract and breathtakingly simple, died on March 17 at his home in Sussex, England. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As CNN+ debuts new show, Chris Wallace talks about leaving Fox News.
description: Mr. Wallace spoke to The Times about his decision to leave Fox News and join the new streaming platform.
content: In his first extensive interview about his decision to leave Fox News, Chris Wallace told The New York Times that he “just no longer felt comfortable with the programming at Fox.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Michael S. Schmidt and Luke Broadwater
title: New Focus on How a Trump Tweet Incited Far-Right Groups Ahead of Jan. 6
description: Federal prosecutors and congressional investigators are documenting how the former president’s “Be there, will be wild!” post became a catalyst for militants before the Capitol assault.
content: Federal prosecutors and congressional investigators have gathered growing evidence of how a tweet by President Donald J. Trump less than three weeks before Jan. 6, 2021, served as a crucial call to action for extremist groups that played a central role in storming the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: California to Parole Man Who Kidnapped 26 Children on School Bus
description: Frederick Woods, 70, was one of three men convicted in the 1976 kidnapping in Chowchilla, Calif. The children and the bus driver escaped after being buried in a trailer for 16 hours.
content: It was a crime that stunned the nation: A school bus carrying 26 children in Chowchilla, a farm town in Central California, was ambushed by three masked kidnappers who demanded a $5 million ransom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: More Private Jets Take to the Skies, Creating Gridlock on the Ground
description: Developers are rapidly expanding hangar space at airports across the country to keep up with a growing demand for places to park private planes.
content: When Mike Pellitteri started flying his private plane in 2013, it was easy to find a spot to park it. But over the past decade, hangar space has become sparse, so Mr. Pellitteri, a general contractor, has joined an increasing number of developers who have never worked in aviation before: He’s building hangars himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Daniel Berehulak
title: In Kyiv Suburb, Ukrainian Military Claims a Big Prize
description: Ukrainian soldiers have essentially retaken, for now, the town of Irpin, the scene of fierce fighting in recent weeks. Its success shows the steep challenges Russia faces in trying to capture Ukraine’s capital.
content: IRPIN, Ukraine — Creeping forward block by block, Ukrainian soldiers in a reconnaissance unit on Tuesday found signs of a retreating Russian army everywhere: a charred armored vehicle, abandoned body armor decorated with an orange and black St. George ribbon, a Russian military symbol, and the traditional blue-and-white striped underwear issued to Russian soldiers, cast aside in a forest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: Art Market Grew 29% in 2021, Says Key Report (Though Some Doubt It)
description: A much-referenced annual study found the market had recovered to prepandemic levels. Some industry observers question the methodology.
content: LONDON — International art sales “recovered strongly” after a pandemic-blighted year, according to the latest annual Art Basel & UBS Global Art Market Report, published on Tuesday. Sales reached an estimated $65.1 billion, up 29 percent on the previous year, the report says — but that headline figure, combining auction and gallery sales, remains short of the trade’s estimated $68.2 billion peak in 2014.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Scott Joplin’s Ragtime Is Ambrosia. Here’s Why It Matters.
description: Notes on a great American composer.
content: Friday is the anniversary of Scott Joplin’s death in 1917. The story of this Black master of the ragtime genre can seem like one that never got far beyond the starting gate and ended with a sad decrescendo. He was raised in and around Texarkana, Texas, at turns made a living as a cornet player and a singer, and eventually published the best ragtime piano pieces of his era. He blended Black American syncopated rhythms and bluesy harmonies with European-derived classical and semiclassical forms, such as marches and waltzes, to create a new music shining with indigenous authenticity and refinement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Hillsong, Once a Leader of Christian Cool, Loses Footing in America
description: Amid a series of crises, including the resignation of its leader, the evangelical powerhouse has shed more than half its American churches in just a few weeks.
content: Terry Crist, a fifth-generation pastor in Phoenix, joined the global megachurch Hillsong in part because of what he describes as its distinctly joyful approach to church life: Hillsong was an institution where leaders seemed “light and free,” offering a church experience that attracted tens of thousands of people around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: Ralph Lauren Goes Back to School
description: In a new collaboration with Morehouse and Spelman colleges, Ralph Lauren honors the style legacy of Black students.
content: ATLANTA — Upon arriving at Morehouse College, the prestigious historically Black men’s college in Atlanta, students quickly learn that a man of Morehouse must be “well-read, well-spoken, well-traveled, well-dressed and well-balanced.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Texas Wildfire Grows to 33,000 Acres, but Poses Little Threat
description: The Crittenberg Complex fire near Fort Hood could burn for more several days, if not weeks, a fire official said on Monday.
content: A fast-moving wildfire near Fort Hood, a sprawling military base in Texas, continues to grow in size but poses no threat to lives, homes or infrastructure, fire officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Peace Talks Produce Signs of Progress, but No End to War Is in Sight
description: Russia said it would “drastically” reduce military activity around Kyiv, while Ukraine said it would be willing to accept neutrality and discuss territorial claims to resolve the conflict.
content: ISTANBUL — The first signs of significant progress in peace talks between Russia and Ukraine emerged on Tuesday, but there was no hint of an imminent end to the suffering, with Russia appearing determined to capture more territory in eastern Ukraine and officials predicting that weeks of further negotiation were needed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Biden Administration Will Start Vaccinating Migrants at Border
description: Some migrants who refuse will be detained and placed in removal proceedings, according to directions given to homeland security officials.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is requiring coronavirus vaccines for some undocumented migrants at the southwest border, a policy change that comes days before the administration’s next review of a public health order that has limited immigration during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: At Sarah Lawrence Cult Trial, Bronx Siblings Describe Their Ordeal
description: Lawrence V. Ray turned a brother and sister against each other with threats and lies, they testify.
content: Lawrence V. Ray grunts and screams on the audio recording. He asks for his “sharpest razor,” calls for a hammer and yells at a young man named Santos Rosario.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelia Herrera
title: Daddy Yankee, Reggaeton’s First Global Star, Steps Aside
description: For “Legendaddy,” an album billed as his last, the reggaeton forefather surveys the shifting styles that shaped his career.
content: Plunge into the recesses of YouTube, and you’ll find a video of Daddy Yankee performing live in his late teens, wearing a silver zip-up windbreaker and a creeping caterpillar mustache. It was 1996, and the future global ambassador of reggaeton freestyled a cappella to a crowd of hundreds. He flaunted a breathless flow with touches of Patois intonation, a signature of the time, when the genre “underground” — a predecessor to reggaeton — was flourishing. The D.J. dropped a beat, chopping drum breaks and syncopated dembow riddims. Yankee effortlessly kept up, brandishing the hyperspeed raps that would make him a superstar in the next decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Charles M. Blow, Roxane Gay and Esau McCaulley
title: Four Opinion Writers on Will Smith’s Slap: ‘There Are No Heroes in This Story’
description: Charles Blow, Roxane Gay and Esau McCaulley join Lulu Garcia-Navarro to discuss why the incident has elicited so many passionate responses.
content: Will Smith’s slap has already launched a thousand takes. On Sunday evening at the Academy Awards, the actor struck Chris Rock after the comedian joked about his wife’s shaved head. (Jada Pinkett Smith has alopecia, a condition that leads to hair loss.) Later in the evening, when Smith won his first Oscar, he apologized onstage, saying, “Love will make you do crazy things.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: What if Putin Didn’t Miscalculate?
description: It’s always wiser to treat an adversary as a canny fox, not a crazy fool.
content: The conventional wisdom is that Vladimir Putin catastrophically miscalculated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Brother-in-Law Is Awful to His Girlfriend. Should I Break Them Up?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to intervene when a family member is in an emotionally damaging relationship — and more.
content: My brother-in-law has been dating his partner longer than my husband and I have been together. They have stayed together through many trials, job changes and relocations, but he does not seem that interested in her. He constantly tells her that she is not making enough money; she abandoned her dream job in favor of a more lucrative one. Over the holidays, she expressed the desire to try to get into the same field as me, which makes me think that my brother-in-law is making unfair comparisons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Nielsen agrees to $16 billion private equity takeover.
description: The company known for TV ratings has faced pressure from media platforms and advertisers to more accurately include digital audiences.
content: The media measurement firm Nielsen Holdings, facing intense competition and criticism as it tries to make the transition to digital audience tracking from its longstanding TV business, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to be acquired by a private equity consortium for $16 billion, including debt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Homeland Security Is Making Plans to Handle a Record Surge of Migrants
description: Officials are bracing for the number of interceptions at the border to rise much higher if a public health order that has limited immigration during the pandemic is lifted.
content: WASHINGTON — Crossings at the southwest border have been peaking again in recent weeks, and homeland security officials are bracing for those numbers to rise much higher if the Biden administration decides to lift a public health order that has limited immigration during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti, Michael Wines and Patricia Mazzei
title: G.O.P. Presses for Greater Edge on Florida and Ohio Congressional Maps
description: In Florida, Gov. Ron DeSantis vetoed a map drawn by his fellow Republicans in the Legislature. In Ohio, Republicans closed in on a G.O.P.-friendly map for the midterm elections.
content: With the midterm election cycle fast approaching, Republicans in the key states of Florida and Ohio have made critical progress in their push to add to their dominance on congressional maps by carving new districts that would be easier for G.O.P. candidates to win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: How to Defeat Putin and Save the Planet
description: The technology is here. We can now put Putin over a barrel. It is just a matter of leadership and national will.
content: It is impossible to predict how the war in Ukraine will end. I fervently hope it’s with a free, secure and independent Ukraine. But here is what I know for sure: America must not waste this crisis. This is our umpteenth confrontation with a petro-dictator whose viciousness and recklessness are possible only because of the oil wealth he extracts from the ground. No matter how the war ends in Ukraine, it needs to end with America finally, formally, categorically and irreversibly ending its addiction to oil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Peace Talks May Be Little More Than Russian Tactics, Analysts Say
description: As signs of progress emerged during the peace talks, some saw them as Russia buying time to regroup its military forces before another offensive push in Ukraine.
content: BRUSSELS — As envoys made progress in peace talks on Tuesday, Russia offered concessions that signaled a more realistic course for the war in Ukraine, while indicating it is also in no hurry to end the conflict, according to diplomats and analysts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Apple and the Streaming Mirage
description: Apple’s “CODA” won the Oscar for best picture. Cool. But what happens when Big Tech stops throwing money around?
content: A film from Apple, “CODA,” this week became the first movie from a streaming service to win the Oscar for best picture. The milestone means that the Hollywood establishment is finally accepting movies and TV series that we watch over internet connections as legitimate entertainment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Ice Volcanoes Reshape Pluto and Hint at a Hidden Ocean
description: Signs of cryovolcanic activity on the dwarf planet in the recent geological past must be driven by an underground body of water, a study suggests.
content: In July 2015, NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft gave humanity its only close-up of Pluto. The spacecraft found that the dwarf planet, far from being a featureless and frigid orb, was an ostentatious world with epic impact craters, methane ice and nitrogen snow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Mental Health Providers Are Busier Than Ever. Here’s How to Find One.
description: Tips and tricks to get help now.
content: Finding a therapist — let alone one who is a good fit — can take time and determination, especially during the pandemic, when many therapists report they cannot keep up with demand and must turn away patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Stray Kids, a K-Pop Octet, Debuts on the Chart at No. 1
description: The eight-member group sold more than 100,000 copies of its new mini-album, “Oddinary,” on CD, which came in an array of collectible versions.
content: Stray Kids, a K-pop group formed through a reality-TV show, has made its first appearance on the Billboard 200 chart a big one, opening at No. 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Tackles the Will Smith ‘Hitch’ Slap
description: “It was so shocking,” Jimmy Kimmel said. “The only thing I can really compare it to is when Mike Tyson bit Evander Holyfield’s ears.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: After Mass Shooting, a Town in Arkansas Struggles to Move Forward
description: Dumas, Ark., has been shrinking steadily, but the diaspora returned each year for a festival that united scattered friends and family. Organizers say its future is now uncertain.
content: DUMAS, Ark. — The small city of empty storefronts and vacant lots that is Dumas, Ark., has seen its population drain away steadily over the decades. But each spring, people of the diaspora have made their way along two-lane country roads, driving through cotton fields and catfish farms and finally  into Dumas for Hood-Nic, the community’s big “neighborhood picnic,” which serves as an informal homecoming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: Jada Pinkett Smith Shouldn’t Have to ‘Take a Joke.’ Neither Should You.
description: A defense of thin skin.
content: This is not a defense of Will Smith, who does not need me to defend him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: How Australia Became an N.B.A. Point Guard Pipeline
description: The N.B.A. Global Academy has developed a reputation for training elite young passers, including Josh Giddey, the sixth overall pick in last year’s draft.
content: Last July, a group of tall and excited teenagers gathered in a conference room in Canberra, Australia, to watch the N.B.A. draft on television. As the technical director of the N.B.A. Global Academy, Marty Clarke was responsible for getting them out of class on a school day so they could watch as a former teammate, Josh Giddey, achieved his dream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to See Faces Everywhere
description: It’s a natural human tendency. Give yourself the time and space to look out into the world in a curious, aimless way.
content: “Your brain is superattuned to see faces everywhere,” says Susan Wardle, a scientist who studies how and why people see illusory faces in objects, a phenomenon known as “face pareidolia.” Humans are hypersocial animals. We’re constantly looking for one another out in the world — to find love, avoid danger, connect — so much so that we often see a face where there isn’t one. “You only need this minimal information to see a face because it’s more adaptive to make a mistake and see a funny face in a cloud than to miss a real human face,” says Wardle, who works at the Laboratory of Brain and Cognition at the National Institute of Mental Health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Elevator Woes: Down in the Dumps on the 59th Floor
description: Residents of an expensive Financial District high-rise are contending with frequent elevator breakdowns.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at a high-rise building where residents can’t count on the elevators. We’ll also take note of Alligator in the Sewer Day, which had to be postponed because of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alina Tugend
title: How Robots Can Assist Students With Disabilities
description: New tools use artificial intelligence to assist students with autism and dyslexia and address accessibility for those who are blind or deaf.
content: This article is part of a limited series on how artificial intelligence has the potential to solve everyday problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Joan Collins Just Gets on With It
description: The actress (don’t call her an actor, please) reflects on her seven-decade career, predatory Hollywood and why sometimes it’s better not to relive the past.
content: LOS ANGELES — “I’m not a bad girl,” said Joan Collins, draped across a white sofa. “I was a very innocent girl. But I had dark hair and green eyes and I suppose they said that I smoldered.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Does Moderate Drinking Protect Your Heart? A Genetic Study Offers a New Answer.
description: By studying the relationship between gene variants and alcohol consumption, scientists found no real cardiac benefit to drinking, even modestly.
content: Last week, two patients asked Dr. Stanley L. Hazen, a cardiologist at the Cleveland Clinic, how much daily alcohol consumption would be good for their cardiac health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chloé Cooper Jones
title: Contemplating Beauty in a Disabled Body
description: My looks don’t fit into classical ideals of order, proportion, symmetry. So what was I looking for in that gallery in Rome?
content: The stranger is staring at me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Why a Ruling Declaring Trump ‘Likely’ Broke Laws May Not Mean He Will Be Prosecuted
description: A high-profile ruling about a subpoena from the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack turned on a lower standard of proof than a criminal trial.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge’s conclusion this week that former President Donald J. Trump likely committed felonies related to his efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 election intensified scrutiny on the question of whether the Justice Department can, should or will try to charge him with the same crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Ramsey
title: Marina Goldovskaya, 80, Dies; Filmmaker Documented Russian Life
description: In about 30 documentaries she looked at the people and history of her homeland, some of it brutally dark.
content: Marina Goldovskaya, an acclaimed documentary filmmaker who exposed the harsh underbelly of the Soviet Union’s labor camps and later chronicled the heady days that followed the state’s collapse — days that promised democracy but bordered on anarchy — died on March 20 in Jurmala, Latvia. She was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: contortion
description: This word has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word contortion has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 16 in the dance review “Reveling in Live Dance at Japan Society” by Brian Seibert:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: California Hopes to Balance Legislation From Conservative States
description: State leaders are drafting laws to make California a sanctuary for people seeking abortions and for transgender youth.
content: More than ever, California is positioning itself as a state that fights back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Twenty-one states file a lawsuit to block the mask mandate on public transportation.
description: Twenty-one Republican state attorneys general filed a lawsuit against the Biden administration on Tuesday to block the federal mask mandate on public transportation.
content: Twenty-one Republican state attorneys general filed a lawsuit against the Biden administration on Tuesday to block the federal mask mandate on public transportation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trisha Pasricha
title: Why Am I Bloated All the Time?
description: And is there anything I can do about it?
content: Q: I feel bloated every day. What could be causing it? And is there anything I can do to find relief?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Nancy Wartik
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Ukraine Talks Appear to Progress
description: And new lockdowns frustrate Shanghai, plus Afghans toil in deadly mines.
content: In the most significant sign of progress to date at talks in Turkey, Moscow promised to sharply “reduce military activity” near Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, and Chernihiv, a besieged northern city. Russia said a meeting between President Vladimir Putin and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine could occur once a draft peace agreement was ready, though analysts said such talk may be just a tactic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Don Young of Alaska, the House Dean, Leaves an Earmark Legacy
description: The Alaska Republican lay in state on Tuesday in the Capitol, where he was renowned for his virtuosity with earmarking federal money for his state.
content: WASHINGTON — It began the year Representative Don Young was sworn in to Congress in 1973, when he won House approval to build the Trans-Alaska Pipeline that would zigzag across his state, through mountain ranges and rivers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geoffrey Wheatcroft
title: Dark Truths About Britain’s Imperial Past
description: Caroline Elkins’s “Legacy of Violence” details the terrible price paid by peoples under the rule of the British Empire.
content: LEGACY OF VIOLENCEA History of the British EmpireBy Caroline Elkins
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: The BA.2 subvariant of Omicron accounts for over half of new U.S. coronavirus cases, the C.D.C. says.
description: Scientists have been keeping an eye on BA.2, one of three distinct genetically distinct varieties of the Omicron variant of the coronavirus.
content: The highly contagious Omicron subvariant known as BA.2, which led to a surge of coronavirus cases in Europe, is now the dominant version of the virus in new U.S. cases, according to estimates from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins, Ben Hubbard and Gina Kolata
title: Once the Children Got Hungry, ‘the Fire Was Gone From Their Eyes’
description: Residents of Mariupol, Ukraine described how Russian forces use hunger as a weapon of war in a monthlong siege of the southern port. “No roof, no food and no water,” survivors texted relatives who escaped.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — After Russian forces surrounded the city of Mariupol in southern Ukraine, cutting off its water and fuel and preventing aid convoys from entering, Yulia Beley sheltered in a neighbor’s basement with her three daughters and struggled to survive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In Jennifer Egan’s New Novel, Our Memories Are Available for All to See
description: Egan’s “The Candy House,” a sequel to her Pulitzer Prize-winning “A Visit From the Goon Squad,” comes alive in dozens of entwined stories.
content: Do you have to have a high I.Q. to be a good fiction writer? John Cheever worried about his, which was under 110 — too low to qualify him for the Army’s Officer Candidate School during World War II. Cheever took several I.Q. tests and read a book about how to improve his score, but it remained about the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Ginni Thomas Is No Outlier
description: There’s very little distance between the fringes of the modern Republican Party and the elites who lead it.
content: At this point, there’s very little distance between the fringes of the modern Republican Party and the elites who lead it. Superficial differences of affect and emphasis mask shared views and ways of seeing. In fact, members of the Republican elite are very often the fringe figures in question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: I Keep Hoping Larry Summers Is Wrong. What if He’s Not?
description: The former Treasury secretary discusses inflation, a possible recession and how the Russia-Ukraine war might exacerbate both.
content: “There is a chance that macroeconomic stimulus on a scale closer to World War II levels than normal recession levels will set off inflationary pressures of a kind we have not seen in a generation,” wrote Larry Summers in February 2021. A year later, the debate still rages over the first part of that sentence — the extent to which the American Rescue Plan is responsible for rising prices. But the rest of it is no longer in question: We’re currently experiencing the worst inflationary crisis in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Here’s what Biden’s budget would do, and not do, for climate change
description: The president’s federal spending proposal for the next year contains almost $45 billion to deal with global warming. We looked at the details.
content: On Day 1 of his presidency, Joseph R. Biden Jr. brought the United States back into the global climate accord. His administration made bold pledges to cut emissions. It urged other countries to set ambitious climate targets of their own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mélissa Godin
title: A Climate Warrior’s Journey From Summit Talks to Street Protests
description: After a high-profile career as an international lawyer and negotiator, Farhana Yamin decided “we cannot rely on lawyers and diplomats alone.”
content: It took 20 minutes for police officers to unglue Farhana Yamin from Shell’s offices in London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Britain detains a Russian superyacht in London.
description: The British authorities have joined those nations putting pressure on Vladimir Putin by targeting the assets of his wealthy supporters.
content: LONDON — It is called the Phi, and the sleek 192-foot-long superyacht worth about $50 million, which has a wine cellar and swimming pool, is a display of wealth that stands out even in a capital known for its ultrarich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Could the U.S. Do More?
description: President Biden says that Ukraine has the full support of the U.S. Volodymyr Zelensky disagrees.
content: President Biden, in a passionate speech from Warsaw on Saturday, proclaimed the West’s complete support for Ukraine. “We stand with you, period,” Biden said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Uncle Lou Is a Restaurant for People Who Love Chinatown
description: The menu is loaded with Cantonese dishes that long ago became neighborhood standards.
content: Each time I go to Uncle Lou, the dining room looks busier than the time before. More couples are seated at the rows of two-tops along the exposed-brick walls, more (and bigger) families are circled around the lazy susans on the round tables that run down the middle of the space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Piano Lesson’ With Samuel L. Jackson Plans Fall Broadway Bow
description: The revival of August Wilson’s play, directed by LaTanya Richardson Jackson, will also star Danielle Brooks and John David Washington.
content: LaTanya Richardson Jackson first saw August Wilson’s “The Piano Lesson” in 1987 — it was the original production, at Yale Repertory Theater, and of course she was going to see it, because her husband, Samuel L. Jackson, was in the cast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel E. Gross
title: Ovaries Are Prone to ‘Exhaustion’ and ‘Fatigue.’ Or Are They?
description: Is it time to rethink the potential of a much-maligned female organ?
content: Women, you may have heard, are born with all the eggs they will ever have. It’s one of those factoids that gets repeated ad nauseam in medical textbooks, health magazines and high school biology classrooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: Desserts That Rival the Main Menu
description: These six restaurants (and one cafe) see the importance of an impressive dessert offering.
content: There’s this fantastic song by the R&B artist Tinashe and the D.J. MAKJ called “Save Room for Us,” and I hear it in my head every time I sit down at a restaurant that I know has a dessert menu. It’s a subject I just won’t shut up about, because when done right, dessert can elevate an already wonderful meal. Without it, you’re making it all the way to the end zone — only to score a field goal. (In nonsports parlance, it’s like a Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade without Snoopy — it’s still great, but it feels incomplete!)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: A Day of World Cup Drama Goes Down to the Last Kick
description: In Algeria, a berth in Qatar changed hands in an instant. In Senegal, a shootout settled another long night. And in Portugal, Cristiano Ronaldo set up one final hurrah.
content: Algeria’s players were strewn on the turf, their faces covered, their chests heaving. Their coach, Djamel Belmadi, seemed frozen by shock. Tears streamed from his eyes. The moment they had been waiting for, the goal that would send them to the World Cup, took 118 minutes to arrive. They had their last-minute winner. And then, in an instant, so did Cameroon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivek H. Murthy and David A. Kessler
title: America Is Running Out of Money to Fight Covid
description: Two federal health officials call for more Covid-19 funding.
content: Over the last two years, the United States has made extraordinary progress in the fight against Covid-19. That progress is now threatened by Congress’s failure to fund the continuing Covid-19 response effort. The federal government is running out of funds to provide Americans, especially those who are uninsured, with Covid-19 vaccines, tests and treatments. Our efforts to sustain other critical elements of the public health response, from Covid-19 surveillance to the global vaccination campaign, are also now at risk.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Our Most Mundane Conversations Became Contentious’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Long before her diagnosis, my reliably cheerful friend turned sour. Even our most mundane conversations became contentious. Pessimism and frustration darkened her world. Eventually, as words eluded her and her thinking grew disorganized, the diagnosis came: early dementia. Terrifying, yes, but naming her condition set her free. Her joy returned in force. Now, when I visit her in her assisted-living apartment, a smile lights her face. Complex sentences are out of her reach. Instead, she pours out pure love — telling me I’m wonderful, beautiful and smart. Her son says her happiness lasts for hours after our visits. — Elise Gibson
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Inside Biden’s $5.8 Trillion Wish List
description: The White House’s latest budget proposal enumerates its biggest policy priorities.
content: President Biden proposed a $5.8 trillion annual budget yesterday, a request that reflects growing security and economic concerns at home and abroad. There are billions set aside to invest in police departments and the military, paid for in part by higher taxes on corporations and the wealthy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: London Police Issue Fines for Downing Street Lockdown Parties
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson was not among those penalized, his office said, but the police decision puts a perilous political scandal back in the spotlight.
content: LONDON — Reviving a politically dangerous scandal for Prime Minister Boris Johnson, the London police on Tuesday levied 20 fines on people accused of breaching Covid lockdown restrictions by attending social gatherings at 10 Downing Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Prince Andrew, Banished From Royal Duties, Escorts Queen to Memorial
description: The prince’s conspicuous public appearance at the service for his father, Prince Philip, who died last year, sent an unmistakable message of support by a 95-year-old mother for her disgraced son.
content: LONDON — Six weeks ago, Prince Andrew agreed to a multi-million-dollar legal settlement with a woman who accused him of raping her when she was a teenager. On Tuesday, he escorted his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, to a memorial service at Westminster Abbey to celebrate the life of her late husband, Prince Philip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘How to Survive a Pandemic’ Review: Racing for a Shot
description: The director David France’s new documentary, about the global effort to develop and disseminate vaccines for the coronavirus, inspires striking candor from some of its subjects.
content: A decade after receiving an Oscar nomination for his documentary “How to Survive a Plague,” about the work of the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power in the 1980s and ’90s that led to the development of antiviral treatments for AIDS, the director David France returns with what we might — depressingly — call a sequel: “How to Survive a Pandemic,” about the global effort to develop and disseminate vaccines for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbey Bender
title: Why I Love Erotic Thrillers
description: They are best consumed as escapist fantasies about a mythic figure I myself could never embody: the femme fatale.
content: I can trace my fascination with erotic thrillers back to the 1998 Neve Campbell and Denise Richards vehicle “Wild Things.” My father and I watched it together at his suggestion (there was never much censorship in my bohemian Manhattan childhood home), and as a burgeoning teen cinephile I was enchanted by its polished, artful sleaze. The plot concerns Campbell (brunette, surly, poor) and Richards (blonde, popular, wealthy), who accuse their high-school guidance counselor of abuse. Soon, the story becomes a thicket of convoluted double crosses, and nothing is what it originally seemed. By the time the end credits rolled and revealed Campbell as the film’s criminal mastermind, I was ready to cheer. Like many of the most captivating women in these films, Campbell’s character is an outsider who uses others’ underestimation of her abilities to her advantage. Fooled by her lower-class status, her enemies think she lacks savvy, but she is in fact a cunning strategist who uses her sexuality to outwit them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yuval Levin
title: Why Do Our Politicians Keep Pursuing a Losing Strategy?
description: Consistently close elections and polarization have blinded both parties.
content: In the spring of a new president’s second year in office, political junkies know all too well what to expect from the midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: L’Abeille, Serving French Fare With Casual Elegance, Opens in TriBeCa
description: A third location for Momoya Soho, a lounge disguised as a locksmith and shoe repair, and more restaurant news.
content: From the start, TriBeCa’s conversion from warehouse district to restaurant hub has featured opulent, high-end dining destinations. Think Chanterelle, Montrachet, Bouley, Mr. Chow and Danube. This has not changed: More recent additions include One White Street, Atera, Jungsik and now this restaurant, set in a former coffee and tea warehouse. The executive chef and a partner, Mitsunobu Nagae, is serving French fare with Japanese touches in a setting at once informal, with no tablecloths, and luxuriously appointed with plush snow-pea velvet. Mr. Nagae, 34, who is from Osaka, worked in Paris at Le Doyen before moving onto the Joël Robuchon empire, including L’Atelier in New York, and later Shun. When he wound up at loose ends once the pandemic closed down restaurants, Rahul Saito, an affluent local resident with a taste for fine food, tapped him for this new enterprise. They define it with the French term “bistronomie,” meaning a bistro for elegant dining. As for the restaurant’s name, it’s a sly reference to the Mitsu, meaning honey, in the chef’s name. (“Abeille” means “bee” in French.) Mr. Nagae’s menu includes pigeon glazed with miso and grilled over binchotan charcoal, lobster marinated with vanilla vinaigrette, and a dessert of strawberries with lychee, rose and shiso. There’s a six-course tasting menu, $180, in addition to à la carte. French bottles and especially Champagnes dominate the wine list, which is curated by John Mckenna, the beverage director.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Ukraine reports some battle successes.
content: Ukrainians reported yesterday that they had pushed back invading Russian forces in heavy fighting around Kyiv, the capital, and in northeastern Ukraine. The mayor of Irpin, a fiercely contested suburb on the northwestern edge of the capital, said that most Russian troops had retreated, though fighting continued in some districts. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner
title: Eluding an Array of Upsets, Four Powers Remain
description: The Final Four features three No. 1 seeds, South Carolina, Stanford and Louisville, and the blue blood Connecticut. But it hasn’t been an easy tournament for favorites.
content: The women’s Final Four are crowded with top seeds and familiar faces. There are the reigning champions, No. 1 seed Stanford; the season-long favorites and top overall seed, South Carolina; an ascendant program with deep runs on its résumé but no title (yet) in No. 1 seed Louisville; and a Final Four fixture, No. 2 seed Connecticut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Wilson
title: The Scars of Ukraine’s War, Illuminated in Fiction
description: Two newly translated books highlight everyday lives transformed by conflict.
content: In 2019, I read about a condition called uterine prolapse; it occurs when weakened pelvic muscles cause the uterus to detach, drop down into the vagina, and in some cases, even slip out. I learned that more cases than usual were being reported in a city in the Donbas region of Ukraine, where skirmishes between Russian-backed separatists and the Ukrainian Army had left the area war-ravaged long before the full-scale invasion currently strangling the country. A gynecologist in Avdiivka, a suburb of Donetsk, told The New York Times that the uptick in cases was most likely due to a combination of stress and heavy lifting; damage to pipes and other infrastructure forced residents to carry pails of water up flights of stairs. One woman with the condition, Liudmila, said she now had to decide between an expensive medical procedure and repairing her roof, which had been destroyed by shelling. “The winter is coming,” she said, “and I am going to stay either without a roof over my head or with my uterus falling out.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: A Brutal Russian Playbook Reapplied in Ukraine
description: The besieging of cities, the deliberate targeting of civilians — they are the tactics Russia used before, in Grozny. I saw it firsthand.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — In Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, amid the deadly rumble of heavy Russian artillery, there is much that feels familiar. Not least a terrible feeling of dread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: ‘Vagina Obscura’ Demystifies Female Anatomy
description: There’s a reason women know so little about our own bodies.
content: VAGINA OBSCURAAn Anatomical VoyageBy Rachel E. Gross
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Haley Mlotek
title: Stop Telling Single People to Put Themselves ‘Out There’
description: For the women in Kate Folk’s debut story collection, it might be safer to just be alone.
content: OUT THERE Stories By Kate Folk
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Michael Simon Johnson, Stella Tan, Rachelle Bonja, Rikki Novetsky, Paige Cowett, Brad Fisher, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Senator Joe Manchin’s Conflict of Interest
description: How the West Virginia lawmaker intervened on behalf of a coal plant, and earned millions along the way.
content: At every step of his political career, Senator Joe Manchin III has helped a West Virginia power plant that is the sole customer of his private coal business, including by blocking ambitious climate action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Kirschbaum
title: A Model’s Refugee Story
description: Irina Lazareanu has a new book about her life in fashion. But it was her life before fashion that haunts her now.
content: It was the recent Paris Fashion Week, and model Irina Lazareanu was experiencing a disorienting sense of déjà vu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: For UConn, a Rougher Path Than Usual Still Leads to the Final Four
description: After injuries, losses to unranked teams and a second-round scare, the Huskies advanced to their 14th straight Final Four by beating No. 1-seeded North Carolina State.
content: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — There were, after all these years, reasons to doubt the Connecticut women’s basketball team almost all season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Petersen
title: Where Breaking the Ramadan Fast Includes Caribou
description: At America’s northernmost mosque, in Anchorage, nightly potlucks will let Muslims celebrate iftar together over foods from around the globe.
content: Last week, Maleika Jones was still waiting for a package of Ramadan decorations. In her preparations for the monthlong holiday, which in the United States begins on Saturday, she ordered festive lights and trimming to hang up for her family’s celebrations as they break the fast each night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Debating the Grammys’ Biggest, Oddest Category
description: Only in record of the year could Lil Nas X and Olivia Rodrigo face off against Abba and Tony Bennett. Our critics break down all 10 nominees in a new “Diary of a Song” video.
content: At this year’s Grammy Awards, Lil Nas X and Olivia Rodrigo, two of music’s freshest new stars, will face off against Abba and Tony Bennett, some of its sagest.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should I get the booster now? Time it to my summer vacation or the next surge?
description: Antibody levels peak quickly, offering some protection against infection, but then wane over the next two or three months.
content: The protection against infection from booster doses wanes quickly, in just a couple of months, so a booster shot now will not offer much defense in August or even July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘Plaza Suite,’ the Ghosts of #MeToo Haunt the Halls
description: Matthew Broderick and Sarah Jessica Parker star in a Neil Simon comedy that no longer feels very funny.
content: The first thing you see when the curtain goes up on “Plaza Suite” is an aquatint image of that grand hotel in its antique glory. But when it comes to datedness, the faux-French pile that opened its doors in 1907 has nothing on the Neil Simon comedy — itself a faux-French pile — that debuted on Broadway in 1968. Despite the wearying efforts of a likable cast headed by Matthew Broderick and Sarah Jessica Parker, the passage of 54 years is more than enough to reveal the triptych of one-act plays as uninhabitable in 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Experts warn of racial disparities in the diagnosis and treatment of long Covid.
description: Many of the factors that led to higher rates of infection, hospitalization and death among Black Americans will likely lead to an over-prevalence of long Covid symptoms too, a new report found.
content: It has long been clear that Black Americans have experienced high rates of coronavirus infection, hospitalization and death throughout the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reem Kassis
title: The Dessert That Tastes Best One Month Out of Every Year
description: The arrival of qatayef, sweet stuffed pancakes, means Ramadan isn’t far behind.
content: Mohammad Ahmed Mattour has been running Halawiyat Al-Bustan, one of the most famous pastry shops in Ramallah, in the West Bank, since he took it over from his father in 1994. Giant platters of desserts, from baklava and knafeh to basbousa and kullaj, line the windows and shelves year-round. But come Ramadan, the balance of business shifts, and qatayef, stuffed semolina pancakes, take center stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Eduardo Medina
title: M.I.T. Will Again Require SAT and ACT Scores
description: The university said it was reinstating the admissions requirement, which it had waived in 2020 and 2021 because of the pandemic, for the 2022-23 application cycle.
content: Students applying to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 2022 will have to submit SAT or ACT exam scores, the university announced on Monday, nearly two years after suspending the requirement because the pandemic had disrupted testing for many applicants.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Raging Floods Overwhelm Australia’s Government
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, March 29, 2022.
content: “I’m incredibly grateful that I didn’t have to watch my mother die in front of me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: New York’s Bail Laws, Reconsidered: 5 Things to Know
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul is pushing legislative leaders to adopt changes to the state’s bail laws as part of the state budget, due April 1.
content: The most divisive issue in Albany is hardly a new one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Uber Close to Deal for Partnership With San Francisco Taxi Outfit
description: Passengers could soon use the Uber app to order taxis in a deal similar to one recently announced in New York City.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber’s plan to lure more taxis onto its platform in the next several years could soon take another big step.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Yaqoob Akbary and Jim Huylebroek
title: Desperate for Cash, Afghans Toil in Mines That Are Deadlier Than Ever
description: Faced with life-threatening hunger, thousands labor in the coal mines of Baghlan. But safety measures that the former government once provided are gone.
content: CHINARAK COAL MINE, Afghanistan — Choking on dust, Mir Abdul Hadi emerged from the narrow mine shaft with a sack of coal hanging heavy on his back and his skin stained black. For hours he had hacked away at the coal in the dark tunnel, terrified it might collapse on him, and now he was relieved to step back into sunlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Moon Knight’ Review: Raiders of the Lost Identity
description: Oscar Isaac multitasks in a Marvel series about a superhero who answers to an ancient Egyptian god and struggles with dissociative identity disorder.
content: The hero of the new Marvel Comics series, “Moon Knight,” has a superior costume. It’s a cool, bullet-absorbing white suit with a billowing cape and eyeholes that shine like milky spotlights. It makes him look like a luminescent Batman. And he refuses to wear it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: More workers quit in February as job openings stayed high.
description: The job market remained very strong last month, suggesting that workers remain in high demand and are still quitting more often, a Labor Department report showed.
content: Job openings last month remained near record levels, and the number of workers voluntarily leaving their positions increased, the Labor Department said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: At P.S.G., a Different Kind of Champions League Frustration
description: As its star-studded soccer team laments another European disappointment, Paris St.-Germain’s handball team tries (again) to avoid the same pain.
content: Paris St.-Germain has dominated domestic competition for nearly a decade, its team strengthened annually by the signings of expensive stars from around the world. But the title it covets most, the Champions League, remains elusive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Louisville Clinches the Last Spot in the Final Four
description: The Cardinals, playing in their fourth straight regional final, became the third No. 1 seed to reach the national semifinals by beating No. 3-seeded Michigan.
content: WICHITA, Kan. — Olivia Cochran sat most of the first half with foul trouble. She reacted incredulously when what she thought was a clean block was whistled as a foul, and she played the final five minutes of Monday night’s game knowing that one miscue would foul her out for good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: Entrepreneurship Is Alive in N.Y. Public Housing. Will the City Step Up?
description: A new report urges officials to support New York City’s most vulnerable business owners, at a time when jobs lost to the pandemic may take years to return.
content: Many nights, after a long day of home-schooling two of her children, Tamykah Anthony is standing over the stove, cooking up natural beauty products in her kitchen at Queensbridge Houses, the biggest public housing complex in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Comebacks for Wawrinka and Thiem Will Have to Be Continued
description: Once ranked as high as No. 3, the rusty tennis stars used a low-level Challenger event to get back to action after injuries. It was harder than it seemed.
content: Tennis’s minor leagues are still a major challenge. The latest evidence arrived on Tuesday in Marbella, Spain, where Stan Wawrinka and Dominic Thiem, two of the game’s biggest achievers, launched a dual comeback at a low-level Challenger Tour event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: The Wildest Election in America: The Race to Replace Don Young
description: The election to fill the seat of the Alaska congressman, who died last week, promises to be an adventure. It’s also a fascinating political experiment in the making.
content: How do you replace a man who once willingly put his hand in a steel trap during a congressional hearing until it turned blue? Who waggled an 18-inch walrus penis bone at a top administration official? Who held a knife to the throat of a fellow lawmaker?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Hopes for a peace deal center on negotiators at a palace in Istanbul.
description: “All the world is expecting good news from you,” President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said in greeting the Russian and Ukrainian delegations.
content: ISTANBUL — On Tuesday, for the first time in more than two weeks, Ukrainian and Russian negotiators came face to face. They did so over a white tablecloth at a long table inside a 19th-century Ottoman palace on the banks of the Bosporus, welcomed personally by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who greeted them in English with “good morning.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: TV-Themed Trips
description: What world from a television show past or present would you most want to visit? Why?
content: According to a recent article from the Travel section, people are increasingly asking tour guides for immersive, TV-themed itineraries that allow them to live out their favorite shows’ story lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Think ‘OMG! OMG!’
description: Jamey Smith’s puzzle is all about location, location, location.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to the constructor Jamey Smith, who is making his fourth appearance in the New York Times Crossword today. And while this isn’t Mr. Smith’s first puzzle, it’s his first with a theme, as all three of his previous constructions fell on themeless Fridays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Solomon Islands’ Leader Calls Concern Over China Security Deal ‘Insulting’
description: Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare criticized Australia and New Zealand as assuming that the island nation could not act in its own best interests.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — In a fiery speech confirming that the Solomon Islands has drafted a security agreement with China, the island nation’s leader said on Tuesday that the deal was “ready for signing” and criticized as “insulting” concerns from Australia and New Zealand that the pact could destabilize the region’s security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Stream These Three Great Documentaries
description: This month’s nonfiction picks include a surprising look at a World War II veteran and a fresh dive into footage shot during the first year of Putin’s presidency.
content: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: The Slap Wasn’t the Only Astonishing Thing About the Oscars
description: One stretch of the broadcast featured a remarkable convergence of Black celebrities, our critic writes. But in the midst of it all, Will Smith’s victory became a defeat.
content: This pandemic is still killing us. The virus at its center is one of the body. But it’s also costing us our minds. A sacked Capitol building, an invaded and decimated sovereign nation, a raft of refugee crises, more American murders, more overdoses, more harassment — for being Asian, for being Black, for being trans, for being on the subway, for waiting to ride the subway. On Sunday, a couple of hours before the 94th Academy Awards, I watched a man drive the wrong direction down my one-way street. He wasn’t in reverse. His car moved with confidence, with joy, as if this was the way it should be. At the end of the block, he took a right. That was the wrong way, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Royalty Free: The Music of Kevin MacLeod’ Review: Into the Spotlight
description: A musician who gives away most of his music may be heard everywhere, but few know who he is.
content: Kevin MacLeod is arguably the most prolific composer you’ve never heard of — although it’s very likely you’ve heard his music. The Wisconsin-born musician, who has at times resided in New York, is a pioneer both of digital production and distribution. Essentially, he gives much of his music away. Working though the nonprofit organization Creative Commons, he makes his instrumental pieces available either for a one-time fee, or free. His works wind up on YouTube and TikTok videos, in video games, in big-budget studio films (like Martin Scorsese’s “Hugo”) and pornographic movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold and Steven Erlanger
title: Germany’s New Muscular Foreign Policy ‘Lies in the Hands of Strong Women’
description: Angela Merkel is no longer chancellor. But as war rages in Ukraine, a mere 10-hour drive from Berlin, female ministers oversee national security.
content: BERLIN — It was Chancellor Olaf Scholz who, three days after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, broke with Germany’s postwar pacifism, vowing to give his country the necessary resources and muscle to lead on security matters in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Planet Word Survived the Pandemic to Inspire a Love of Language
description: Lexicon Lane, the newest exhibition at Planet Word, opened March 26 and offers word-sleuthing adventures to puzzle-loving visitors.
content: Planet Word, the Washington, D.C., museum dedicated to inspiring a love of language, opened a new permanent exhibit called Lexicon Lane on March 26. A combination escape room and puzzle hunt, Lexicon Lane is designed to resemble an old village and offers 26 unique puzzle “cases” for visitors to solve.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Larry Summers
description: A conversation with former Treasury secretary Larry Summers.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Larry Summers. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Pfizer and Moderna boosters help protect Americans who received J.&J. shots, the C.D.C. reports.
description: The C.D.C. now recommends that all adults who received one or two doses of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine get a booster dose of an mRNA vaccine.
content: Americans who received the single-dose Johnson & Johnson Covid vaccine were better protected against severe illness and hospitalization during the Omicron surge if they received a second dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna vaccines, instead of an additional Johnson & Johnson shot, according to a new study published on Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Suhasini Raj
title: Pro-Russia Sentiment on Indian Twitter Draws Scrutiny
description: While India and Russia have long had close ties, researchers say there are signs that social media posts parroting Kremlin talking points may not be legitimate.
content: In the days after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, thousands of Twitter accounts shared messages of support for Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Gabler
title: The Long Scourge of Lead Poisoning
description: About 500,000 children in the United States have elevated levels of lead in their blood. But it is a problem with a deep past.
content: About 500,000 children in the United States have elevated levels of lead in their blood. But it is a problem with a deep past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis and Jeremy Engle
title: Weekly News Quiz for Students: Academy Awards, National Park Birthday, Teenage Slang
description: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
content: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Don Young Remembered at the Capitol
description: Representative Don Young, Republican of Alaska and the dean of the House, lay in state in National Statuary Hall.
content: Representative Don Young, Republican of Alaska and the dean of the House, lay in state in National Statuary Hall.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A New Location for Old Favorites
description: Cantonese classics, in particular homey dishes from the villages of Guangdong Province, are the focus of Uncle Lou in Manhattan’s Chinatown.
content: Cantonese classics, in particular homey dishes from the villages of Guangdong Province, are the focus of Uncle Lou in Manhattan’s Chinatown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Brent McDonald, Mark Boyer and Benjamin Foley
title: The Fighters Who Took Over a Retail Store to Defend Kyiv
description: As Russia pledges to scale back operations in Kyiv, soldiers from the 112th Brigade of Ukraine’s Territorial Defense Forces are still preparing for the worst. Our cameras went inside their makeshift base.
content: As Russia pledges to scale back operations in Kyiv, soldiers from the 112th Brigade of Ukraine’s Territorial Defense Forces are still preparing for the worst. Our cameras went inside their makeshift base.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli, Meg Felling and Alicia DeSantis
title: Who Will Win the Top Grammy Award? Let’s Discuss.
description: Only in record of the year could Lil Nas X and Olivia Rodrigo face off against Abba and Tony Bennett. Our critics break down all 10 nominees in a new “Diary of a Song” video.
content: Only in record of the year could Lil Nas X and Olivia Rodrigo face off against Abba and Tony Bennett. Our critics break down all 10 nominees in a new “Diary of a Song” video.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Shanghai Residents Face Life Under Lockdown
description: Shanghai imposed a staggered coronavirus lockdown in an effort to test its 26 million residents by splitting the city in half. The measures close the east side for five days before placing a similar shutdown on the west side.
content: Shanghai imposed a staggered coronavirus lockdown in an effort to test its 26 million residents by splitting the city in half. The measures close the east side for five days before placing a similar shutdown on the west side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Pays Respects to Don Young, Alaska Congressman
description: Mr. Young lay in state at the Capitol, where he was honored for his status as the longest-serving House Republican. The former representative of Alaska was 88.
content: Mr. Young lay in state at the Capitol, where he was honored for his status as the longest-serving House Republican. The former representative of Alaska was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Dibdin
title: 6 Advice Podcasts to Navigate the Weirdness of Daily Life
description: After two years of the pandemic, these shows — covering sex and dating, office politics and family dynamics — will help you manage the return to normalcy.
content: American life is largely returning to what it was in early 2020, with even the most Covid-cautious states rolling back their restrictions. Though the return to normalcy is a relief, the abrupt shift feels unsettling to many. After two years of clear guidelines and restrictions, we all have to figure out how to be people in the world again.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 29, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, March 29, 2020.
content: An article on Sunday about the first streaming service film to win an Oscar misstated the year that the film “Parasite” won the Oscar for best picture. It was 2020, not 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Can Movies Survive Changing Times?
description: Readers react to Ross Douthat’s column “Is This the End of the Movies?” Also: Supreme Court ethics; reading “dirty” Shakespeare.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
